results.headline: Solitary Retreat to a Remote Island Leads to Many Mix-Ups

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Your Sister's Sister

results.summary_short: In “Your Sister’s Sister,” Lynn Shelton’s new comedy, the three main characters are engagingly familiar, yet each is a bit of a cipher.

results.headline: Strangers, With Aliens Above

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Extraterrestrial

results.summary_short: In “Extraterrestrial” a young man and a young woman awake after a one-night stand to find Madrid evacuated and a U.F.O. hovering over the city.

results.headline: A Slow Unraveling of Family Secrets

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Americano

results.summary_short: Mathieu Demy, the son of the French filmmakers Agnès Varda and Jacques Demy, makes his feature directing debut with “Americano.”

results.headline: Thriving With the Drug-Cartel Dead

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Night Watchman

results.summary_short: Natalia Almada’s documentary “El Velador” (“The Night Watchman”) photographs a cemetery for those killed in Mexico’s drug wars.

results.headline: Capitalism, Stranger Than a Space Alien

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of UFO In Her Eyes

results.summary_short: “UFO in Her Eyes,” a satire directed by Xiaolu Guo, is now showing at MoMA.

results.headline: Artist’s Fearless Aura, in Film, Chair or Tub
results.display_title: Marina Abramović The Artist is Present

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Marina Abramović The Artist is Present

results.summary_short: The documentary “Marina Abramovic the Artist Is Present” is a portrait more celebratory than analytical of the Yugoslav-born performance artist, directed by Matthew Akers.

results.headline: Adulthood Calling, to Faraway Minds and Lost Ambition

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dark Horse

results.summary_short: “Dark Horse” is a Todd Solondz-directed satire on family relationships and the frequent missteps of adulthood.

results.headline: A Part of Chile About to Change Forever

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Patagonia Rising

results.summary_short: “Patagonia Rising” reminds us that the engine of change is almost always louder than the voices of its victims.

results.headline: Gay Black College Friends Reunite

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Skinny

results.summary_short: In “The Skinny” Patrik-Ian Polk delivers messages about sexual responsibility and abiding friendship, with uneven results.

results.headline: The Only Thing Missing Is a Swamp Monster

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Oregonian

results.summary_short: “The Oregonian” is creepy, silly, startling, irritating and sometimes disgusting.

results.headline: Looking for Themselves in Fading Dreams From the Past and Present

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Safety Not Guaranteed

results.summary_short: Three members of a magazine staff investigate a man who advertises for someone to join him on a trip aboard a time machine.

results.headline: Once More Unto the Galactic Void

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Prometheus

results.summary_short: In “Prometheus,” Ridley Scott returns to the visceral dread of “Alien” as a vessel lumbers through the galactic void.

results.headline: Take It From Grandma, Everything Is Groovy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Peace, Love and Misunderstanding

results.summary_short: In “Peace, Love & Misunderstanding,” it’s the grandmother who is liberating the younger adults.

results.headline: ’70s Troubadour , From Prime Time to Vegas

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paul Williams Still Alive

results.summary_short: This documentary delves into the life of this singer-songwriter, who was one of the forces behind “The Rainbow Connection,” among other songs.

results.headline: They’re Running Away With the Circus

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Madagascar 3: Europe's Most Wanted

results.summary_short: Alex, Marty, Gloria and Melman are fleeing animal control in the latest “Madagascar,” back with some favorites, like the penguins.

results.headline: Once a Criminal, Hard to Turn Back

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of For the Love of Money

results.summary_short: “For the Love of Money” tells what it says is the true story of a man who as a teenager in Israel was surrounded by ominous characters.

results.headline: Wait, the Bus Is Leaving Without Him

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Double Trouble

results.summary_short: Jaycee Chan stars in the action-comedy “Double Trouble,” in the type of role his father perfected.

results.headline: She’s Almost 30 and Starting Over

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lola Versus

results.summary_short: In “Lola Versus,” boy dumps girl. Girl hangs out with wacky friend. Girl does yoga. Girl meets another boy.

results.headline: A Church, and Its Faithful, Both Lost

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Corpo Celeste

results.summary_short: “Corpo Celeste” is a coming-of-age story that is also a kind of metaphor for the Roman Catholic Church, which is portrayed as having lost its way and its faithful.

results.headline: A Parisian Journalist’s Ruthless Liaisons

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bel Ami

results.summary_short: In “Bel Ami,” an adaptation of the Guy de Maupassant novel, Robert Pattinson plays a manipulative journalist who rises through Belle Époque Paris by exploiting a series of women.
